Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Exploring the Intersectional Relationship Between Mathematics and Computing Identities for Black Girls and Women

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will conduct a two-day workshop examining black girls' and women's mathematics and computing identities. The goals of the workshop are to 1) explore the intersectional experiences of black girls and women in math and computer science (CS), 2) begin to understand how math and CS identities relate and inform each other, 3) start understanding factors that lead black women to study math and CS in college, and 4) establish a more extensive research agenda around these issues. The workshop will bring together thought leaders to examine the trajectories of success for black girls and women in mathematics and CS. The results of this workshop will inform the national dialogue in support of broadening participation in both computing and mathematics. The project was funded by the STEM+C program, which focuses on research and development of interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary approaches to the integration of computing within science, technology, engineering, and mathematics teaching and learning and supports research on how students learn to think computationally to solve interdisciplinary problems in the STEM fields.

The contributions of the workshop address the need to increase the diversity of ideas and perspectives in computer science and mathematics, particularly for black women. This workshop will go beyond simply adding to the discourse for the need to increase diversity in these disciplines by 1) actively investigating research to differentiate the experiences of black women from other groups in computing and mathematics, 2) providing a critical analysis of the conditions under which black girls and women thrive, 3) actively investigating the relationship between computer science and mathematics through both curricular and experiential lenses, and 4) engaging black girls and women to articulate the experiences that differentiate them from other groups in computing and mathematics. The organizers will create and distribute an article describing the workshop, its enactment and the findings that emerge from the discussion and interaction. They will also develop a videography of black girls and women sharing how their personal experiences affect their math and CS identities as well as their interest and persistence in these fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While the literature around how the intersectional experiences of women of color inform and impact their mathematics and computing identities is scarce, there is an even greater dearth of literature around these experiences for Black girls and women, though the outcomes of that impact on these identities can be seen.  The purpose of this workshop was to examine the connections between mathematics and computing identities and the ways in which these identities complement and conflict with each other for Black girls and women in computing and mathematics. Presently, there is a dearth of research that examines this relationship. There also exists a need for thought leaders to come together to begin charting a course forward in not only examining this relationship, but also in creating action and awareness round how this relationship impacts Black girls and women and their trajectories for success in these fields. Given the paucity of research around Black girls' and women's experiences in computing and mathematics or an understanding of the impact of their intersectional experiences on their computing and mathematics identities, this workshop will also contribute to the field because it will use critical frameworks (intersectionality, standpoint theory, and BFT) to analyze Black girls' and women’s experiences to illuminate issues of power, oppression, and identity politics and how these issues shape, impact, and inform Black girls' and women's computing and math identities.  We brought together Black feminist theorists, Math educators, and Computer Science educators, and we explored our own lived experiences as well as used our own work and other literature to identify and understand the experiences of Black girls and women in Mathematics and Computer Science.

 

The results of the project gave us a number of new insights.  Computer Science educators discussed the role of Mathematics in the educational pathways for Computing. We came to understand that Mathematics can serve as a gatekeeper into Computing and Computer Science, which often shapes Black girls' and women’s perspectives and identities in terms of fitness for the field and ability to carry out what they perceive to be the practices of the field (i.e., programming, proofs, etc.).  The way(s) in which Mathematics is taught rarely has connection to and applications around Computer Science. It is often taught in isolation, and the connections to other fields (i.e., Computer Science/Engineering/etc.) are lost.  There is a love, as a young student, the early interest in and emergence of numbers and tinkering. Over time, the exposure to different types of programming (summer camps, etc.) are also a part of the factors that lead a Black woman to major into computer Science.  However, once Black girls get into middle school, if they aren't already on the college track, they may not see these opportunities to connect Math to other areas and fields. This happens, in part, because Math is often taught in isolation, but also because of how Black girls are viewed as not being Mathematical thinkers.  We also learned that if teachers and family give sustained reinforcement to Black girls that they are good in Math, that has the power to counter what they may experience in the classroom. 

 

We thought about inquiry as well as praxis in developing a research agenda. The beginnings of a research agenda emerged.  This meeting also inspired the establishment the Center for the Intersectional Study of Black Women and Girls (ISBWG), founded and led by co-PI Nicole Joseph, by creating an organizing committee, of which PI Jakita Thomas is a member.  We have an on-going collective made up of workshop participants that meets on a regular basis to continue the work with different projects as well as the establishment of the ISBWG.
